title: 111_s151
content: The Act titled "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2009" amends Section 5 of the Act related to criminal proceedings and civil actions for misrepresentations in Indian arts and crafts. The "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2009" defines a Federal law enforcement officer and grants them authority to investigate violations of the Act within the United States jurisdiction. The Board can refer violations to Federal law enforcement officers for investigation, specifically regarding section 1159 of title 18, United States Code. Referral is not mandatory for officers to investigate such violations. The Board can recommend criminal proceedings to the Attorney General for violations of section 1159 of title 18, United States Code, following an investigation by a Federal department or agency. The Board can recommend criminal or civil actions to the Attorney General for violations of section 1159 of title 18, United States Code. The Board may provide support to the Attorney General for criminal proceedings and recommend civil actions under section 6 of the Act. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as 'Indian', 'Indian product', and 'Indian tribe', with specific criteria outlined for each term. The definition of 'Indian tribe' includes formally recognized Indian groups. The curr_chunk discusses the formal recognition of an Indian tribe by a State legislature, commission, or similar organization with recognition authority. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The curr_chunk outlines the persons who may initiate civil actions under subsection (b) of the law, including the Attorney General, Indian tribes, individuals of Indian descent, and Indian arts and crafts organizations. The curr_chunk explains that amounts recovered in civil actions under this section are to be paid to the Indian tribe, Indian individuals, or Indian arts and crafts organizations. The Attorney General may deduct costs from the recovered amount in certain cases. Amounts recovered in civil actions under this section are to be paid to the Indian tribe, individuals, or organizations, with the Attorney General deducting costs in certain cases. In civil actions under this section, the Indian tribe can deduct the cost of the action and reasonable attorney's fees from the recovered amount. Additionally, a savings provision is included in subsection (e). SEC. 3. MISREPRESENTATION OF INDIAN PRODUCED GOODS AND PRODUCTS. Section 1159 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for knowingly violating subsection (a), with fines up to $250,000 and imprisonment up to 5 years for individuals, and fines up to $1,000,000 for entities, if the goods involved are priced at $1,000 or more. If goods are sold for less than $1,000, penalties include fines up to $25,000 and imprisonment for individuals, fines up to $100,000 for entities. Subsequent violations result in fines, imprisonment up to 15 years for individuals. In cases involving Indian tribes, fines can reach up to $5,000,000 for entities. The term 'Indian tribe' is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, including formally recognized Indian groups by State entities. State legislative tribal recognition authority allows for the formal recognition of Indian tribes by State entities. The Senate passed the legislation on July 24, 2009, as attested by Nancy Erickson, Secretary.
